block.p: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday announced that it was forming a new subsidiary to engage in the complex swaps business with large clients, including foreign countries and Government agencies.

Swaps transactions are used to adjust the currency rate, interest rate or other characteristics of a security. They involve a promise to make certain payments for up to seven years, so only those with the best credit ratings can participate.
Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday announced that it was forming a new subsidiary to engage in the complex swaps business with large clients, including foreign countries and Government agencies.

Swaps transactions are used to adjust the currency rate, interest rate or other characteristics of a security. They involve a promise to make certain payments for up to seven years, so only those with the best credit ratings can participate.
While Merrill Lynch already has a division in the swaps business, it does not have the high rating that the largest customers demand.

But the developers of the new subsidiary, called Merril Lynch Derivative Products, have structured it in coordination with Moody's Investors Service to obtain a triple-A credit rating. Such a high rating should attract the larger clients, Merrill Lynch executives said.

"It is clear that credit is very important in big parts of the derivative swap market," said Edson V. Mitchell, chairman of Merrill Lynch Derivative Products. "There are a lot of people who would like to do business with us but cannot because we did not have a triple-A entity."
Mr. Mitchell said Merrill Lynch Capital Services, which developed the company's swaps business, would continue to handle the swaps transactions of its current customers.
